headline.main: 41 Shuttle Flights Set, Including First by a Teacher

results.snippet: An American teacher chosen to fly aboard the space shuttle will make the trip next January, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration says.   The agency made public a revised shuttle launching schedule that has nine more flights this year,...
results.lead_paragraph: An American teacher chosen to fly aboard the space shuttle will make the trip next January, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration says. The agency made public a revised shuttle launching schedule that has nine more flights this year, 15 in 1986 and 17 in 1987.

headline.main: DELAYED SHUTTLE TO LIFT OFF FRIDAY

results.snippet: AFTER five postponements in two months, the next space shuttle mission is set for launching Friday morning with a crew of seven ready to deliver two satellites to orbit and conduct several a biological and physiological experiments.   The crew...
results.lead_paragraph: AFTER five postponements in two months, the next space shuttle mission is set for launching Friday morning with a crew of seven ready to deliver two satellites to orbit and conduct several a biological and physiological experiments. The crew plans to operate a drug- producing machine, observe the effects of weightlessness on the human cardiovascular system, study the perplexing nature of space motion sickness and operate 36 experiments in growing protein crystals that could lead to the development of life-saving drugs. In spare moments, the astronauts will play with a spinning top, jacks, magnetic marbles and a yo-yo to demonstrate the behavior of simple toys in a virtual gravity-free environment.

headline.main: LEAK PROBLEM IN EXPERIMENT SOLVED ON EVE OF SHUTTLE'S LAUNCHING

results.snippet: Engineers today contained a leak that threatened a key drug-processing experiment and proceeded with preparations for launching the space shuttle Discovery on a five-day voyage to deliver satellites and study techniques for future space...
results.lead_paragraph: Engineers today contained a leak that threatened a key drug-processing experiment and proceeded with preparations for launching the space shuttle Discovery on a five-day voyage to deliver satellites and study techniques for future space manufacturing. Liftoff for the Discovery is scheduled for 8:04 A.M. Friday, subject to the weather and a smooth countdown in the final hours. The crew of seven, including a United States Senator, will be deploying two communications satellites on the first two days, observing the effects of weightlessness on human physiology and conducting a number of tests of biological products that could lead to life-saving drugs. Hope to Resume Schedule At a news conference, Jesse W. Moore, head of the shuttle project for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said: ''We're ready to fly. We've got the leak under control and also contained. Everything is going well in the processing.''

headline.main: MINORITY FILM ACTORS: FEW, BUT BETTER, ROLES

results.snippet: As recently as 1980, Bill Duke, a black actor who has since become a director, described the status of black actors in Hollywood as ''struggling for crumbs.''    Yet last year two movies with black stars - ''Purple Rain,'' with Prince, and...
results.lead_paragraph: As recently as 1980, Bill Duke, a black actor who has since become a director, described the status of black actors in Hollywood as ''struggling for crumbs.'' Yet last year two movies with black stars - ''Purple Rain,'' with Prince, and ''Beverly Hills Cop,'' with Eddie Murphy - were major hits. In addition, a serious film with a predominantly black cast, ''A Soldier's Story,'' will turn a profit. And one successful movie, ''The Killing Fields,'' was not only about Asians but also co-starred Dr. Haing S. Ngor, a Cambodian who won best supporting actor for his role. He was the first Asian to win an acting Oscar since Miyoshi Umeki took supporting actress honors for ''Sayonara'' in 1957.

headline.main: SHUTTLE LIFTS OFF AFTER RAIN DELAY

results.snippet: A crew of seven, including a United States Senator wired to a medical experiment, rocketed into orbit today aboard the space shuttle Discovery to deliver two satellites and conduct a variety of scientific tests.   The astronauts released a...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: A crew of seven, including a United States Senator wired to a medical experiment, rocketed into orbit today aboard the space shuttle Discovery to deliver two satellites and conduct a variety of scientific tests. The astronauts released a Canadian communications satellite early this evening and plan to deploy a Navy satellite Saturday. The Canadian satellite, Anik C-1, was sent on its course toward a higher equatorial orbit. Commander's Second Mission The mission is commanded by Col. Karol J. Bobko of the Air Force, who is making his second shuttle journey. The most celebrated occupant of the winged spaceship is Senator Jake Garn, Republican of Utah, who is chairman of a Senate subcommittee that oversees the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's budget.

headline.main: SATELLITE LOFTED BUT FAILS TO WORK

results.snippet: Astronauts today released a second communications satellite from the space shuttle Discovery's cargo bay, but a mysterious failure left the satellite powerless and unable to take off on its own to reach its intended higher orbit.   Teams of...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Astronauts today released a second communications satellite from the space shuttle Discovery's cargo bay, but a mysterious failure left the satellite powerless and unable to take off on its own to reach its intended higher orbit. Teams of engineers were studying the possibility of returning the shuttle to the disabled satellite for a close-up inspection and perhaps a space walk by astronauts to restore life to the dormant craft. The inspection could come Monday and the space walk on Tuesday. Satellite Fuel Poses Danger Such an operation, never before attempted, would not be without risk, since the satellite, Leasat 3, is fully fueled and its rocket primed for ignition.

results.snippet: ''James A. Michener's 'Space' '' - that's the offical title - is one of those grand and glossy productions that add up, almost amazingly, to vintage television. The 13- hour mini-series, made at a cost of more than $30 million, gets underway on CBS...
results.lead_paragraph: ''James A. Michener's 'Space' '' - that's the offical title - is one of those grand and glossy productions that add up, almost amazingly, to vintage television. The 13- hour mini-series, made at a cost of more than $30 million, gets underway on CBS this evening at 8 with a three-hour installment. The rest will be broadcast tomorrow through Thursday, which means a significant commitment of time for even the most ardent of viewers. What they will get is not so much Mr. Michener's ''Space'' as Dick Berg's version of the best-selling novel. Mr. Berg is the producer of this television extravaganza and, along with Sterling Silliphant, the co-writer. The overall plot outline and the major characters of the book have been retained, but television's ''Space'' makes its own distinctive adjustments. Mr. Berg has candidly explained: ''What we have tried to do is to make this a mini- series about the relationships between people, not about hardware. We do deal with the technology and we have our special effects, but 'Space' essentially is an adult drama dealing with adult themes in a contemporary, and hopefully fresh, fashion.'' In other words, friends, television's ''Space'' is a kind of ''Dallas'' with astronauts. With a bow to contemporary technology centers, it could be aptly titled ''Houston'' or ''Canaveral.''

results.snippet: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla.      IF a United States Senator can   fly in space, will a sultan be far   behind? Or a schoolteacher? Or a string of guest astronauts from India and Indonesia, China and Mexico or just about any other country with some reason...
results.lead_paragraph: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. IF a United States Senator can fly in space, will a sultan be far behind? Or a schoolteacher? Or a string of guest astronauts from India and Indonesia, China and Mexico or just about any other country with some reason to have one of its own aboard the American space shuttle? It's only a matter of time, according to NASA. The Discovery, launched Friday, is carrying Senator Jake Garn, Republican of Utah, as the first orbiting politician. In the next 41 shuttle missions over 33 months, the guest list will include a schoolteacher (to be selected this summer) and astronauts from nine foreign countries.

results.snippet: When they were not working with their high-technology gear today, the Discovery astronauts took time out to play with their toys. They found that their yo-yo, jacks, Slinky and mechanical mouse did some peculiar things in the  weightlessness of space...
results.lead_paragraph: When they were not working with their high-technology gear today, the Discovery astronauts took time out to play with their toys. They found that their yo-yo, jacks, Slinky and mechanical mouse did some peculiar things in the weightlessness of space flight. One astronaut tried to juggle some oranges and apples. But they just hung there suspended in midair. He had to move them about like chess pieces.

headline.main: SHUTTLE IS USED AS A WORKSHOP IN REPAIR EFFORT

results.snippet: The crew members of the shuttlecraft Discovery turned it into a workshop today as they improvised ''fly swatter'' devices to be attached to the craft's mechanical arm for use - in what would be the first unrehearsed ''walk'' in space - in a bold...
results.lead_paragraph: The crew members of the shuttlecraft Discovery turned it into a workshop today as they improvised ''fly swatter'' devices to be attached to the craft's mechanical arm for use - in what would be the first unrehearsed ''walk'' in space - in a bold attempt to repair a disabled satellite. Dr. Jeffrey A. Hoffman and S. David Griggs were scheduled to attach the ''fly swatter'' to the movable arm in the shuttle's open cargo bay in a space walk to begin sometime after 7 A.M. Eastern standard time Tuesday. Never before have American astronauts undertaken such an arduous task without weeks of careful rehearsal.

headline.main: SPACE SHUTTLE IS POISED TO LAND TODAY

results.snippet: The astronauts aboard the space shuttle Discovery prepared today for a return to earth, ending a mission marked by surprises and frustations, the accomplishment of many objectives and the ''absolutely fantastic'' experience of the first senatorial...
results.lead_paragraph: The astronauts aboard the space shuttle Discovery prepared today for a return to earth, ending a mission marked by surprises and frustations, the accomplishment of many objectives and the ''absolutely fantastic'' experience of the first senatorial space passenger. The winged spaceship is scheduled to land at the Kennedy Space Center here Friday at 7:16 A.M. If necessary, the Discovery could stay in orbit two more days. In their week in space, two days longer than originally planned, the Discovery crew deployed two communication satellites, one for Canada and the other for a Defense Department network. The Canadian satellite worked perfectly. But Leasat 3, owned by the Hughes Aircraft Company and leased to the Navy, failed immediately after deployment and, despite an improvised recovery attempt by the astronauts, was left floating powerless in a useless orbit.

headline.main: SCHOOL VIGILANTE GROUP IS LINKED TO 35 FELONIES

results.snippet: A police investigation of a high school vigilante group that called itself the Legion of Doom indicates it may have been responsible for 35 felonies, including arson and pipe bombings.     The group was made up of some of the school's top athletes...
results.lead_paragraph: A police investigation of a high school vigilante group that called itself the Legion of Doom indicates it may have been responsible for 35 felonies, including arson and pipe bombings. The group was made up of some of the school's top athletes and scholars who said they intended to ''clean up the school, to get rid of people who were doing bad things,'' according to Doug Clarke, public information oficer for the Fort Worth Police Department. ''They claimed they were threatening thieves and dopers.'' Two students and a former student of Paschal High School, rated by local educators as the city's best, have been arrested for questioning but not charged, and six other students who said they were part of the group have made voluntary statements about its activities.

headline.main: ENCOURAGING CHILDREN IN THE 'LONESOME ART' OF COMPOSING

results.snippet: ELIDE SOLOMON knows about the frustrations of a composer's life. As a composer herself and a former teacher of composition, Mrs. Solomon, who is also the founder of the Purchase Music Ensemble, said she wanted to do her part to help make new...
results.lead_paragraph: ELIDE SOLOMON knows about the frustrations of a composer's life. As a composer herself and a former teacher of composition, Mrs. Solomon, who is also the founder of the Purchase Music Ensemble, said she wanted to do her part to help make new musical works heard. ''Composing is a cruel and lonesome art,'' Mrs. Solomon said recently. ''You spend long hours writing, and then only a few people can read what you've written. No one can hear your music, either, unless there's someone willing to play it.''

results.snippet: A welcome sign of spring in Washington is the early arrival of the summer gift catalogue of the Smithsonian Institution. The prose of the descriptive copy is usually as striking as the color pictures of the gifts.

byline.original: By James F. Clarity and Warren Weaver Jr

results.lead_paragraph: A welcome sign of spring in Washington is the early arrival of the summer gift catalogue of the Smithsonian Institution. The prose of the descriptive copy is usually as striking as the color pictures of the gifts.

results.snippet: In the first few minutes of ''Def-Con 4,'' a Canadian melodrama that was shot mostly in Nova Scotia, the crew of a spaceship returns to earth after the end of World War III, which appears to have been started by the Libyan Government.   Thugs of...
results.lead_paragraph: In the first few minutes of ''Def-Con 4,'' a Canadian melodrama that was shot mostly in Nova Scotia, the crew of a spaceship returns to earth after the end of World War III, which appears to have been started by the Libyan Government. Thugs of all types have taken over Nova Scotia, which makes things tough for an honorable astronaut named Howe and a pretty young woman nicknamed J. J., who spend most of the movie trying to get away from the fallout - nuclear and human - and sail to the safety of Central America.

results.snippet: STAR TREKKERS? THEY'VE got only two days more to wait, but Tuesday can't come soon enough for three Long Island teachers who have been in orbit since it was announced that they were among the New York State finalists in NASA's competition to select...
results.lead_paragraph: STAR TREKKERS? THEY'VE got only two days more to wait, but Tuesday can't come soon enough for three Long Island teachers who have been in orbit since it was announced that they were among the New York State finalists in NASA's competition to select the first teacher to go into space. The educators - Susan Agruso, 33 years old, of Coram, a physics teacher at East Islip High School; Paul Stengel, 41, of Water Mill, a physics teacher at Shoreham-Wading River High School, and Richard Posner, 40, of Selden, an English teacher at Sachem North High School - learned two weeks ago that they had been selected as three of the five state finalists. The two other finalists are from Schenectady and Orange County. The five were selected from 721 New York teachers who went through a rigorous application process, writing essays, getting recommendations and developing original proposals for space projects. ''Since I found out I go from nerves to enthusiasm to nerves,'' said Mrs. Agruso, the only female finalist in the state. ''On Tuesday I could be the most depressed person in New York State.''

results.snippet: Four centuries after the Spanish discovered there was no El Dorado hidden in the piney hills above Pensacola, there are hopes once again that this old Gulf port is going to hit pay dirt.   This time hopes are pinned on the Navy's plan to assign a...

byline.original: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Four centuries after the Spanish discovered there was no El Dorado hidden in the piney hills above Pensacola, there are hopes once again that this old Gulf port is going to hit pay dirt. This time hopes are pinned on the Navy's plan to assign a new battleship squadron to the Gulf of Mexico as the military bolsters its ability to meet future tasks in this hemisphere. Pensacola, with its deepwater bay and its naval air station, is considered a leader in the competition for designation this spring as the home port. If Pensacola is chosen, all or most of the squadron's nine large ships of war, including the refitted battleship U.S.S. Wisconsin, would be based here, adding an estimated $50 million a year to the local economy and bringing in 9,000 sailors and their dependents. The naval air station, which dates to 1914, already has some 16,000 officers and enlisted men.
